title: 107_hr1912
content: The Act may be cited as the "Keeping Our Promise to Special Education Act of 2001". The Congress acknowledges the importance of providing equal education opportunities for children with disabilities under the 14th Amendment. It recognizes the need for federal assistance to improve educational outcomes and ensure equal protection of the law. The excess cost of educating a child with a disability is estimated to be 40 percent higher than the national average per pupil expenditure. Congress has committed to supporting these efforts under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. Congress has committed to contributing up to 40 percent of the national average per pupil expenditure for educating children with disabilities. However, the Federal Government has never contributed more than 15 percent of the maximum state grant allocation for this purpose under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The purpose of this Act is to achieve the Federal Government's goal of providing 40 percent of the national average per pupil expenditure for educating all children with disabilities by fiscal year 2011. The Act also specifies the amount of grant for states under Part B of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act specifies the minimum amount of grant a State is entitled to receive based on the number of children with disabilities receiving special education services and the average per-pupil expenditure in public schools. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act specifies the minimum amount of grant a State is entitled to receive for secondary schools in the United States, increasing annually from 20 percent in 2002 to 40 percent in 2011 and subsequent years. No individual is entitled to assistance under this provision. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act does not entitle any individual to assistance under any State program funded under this part. Amendments are made to Section 611 of the Act, including the removal of subsection (j) and changes to the allocation of funds for fiscal years. Amendments are made to Section 611 of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, including changes to fund allocation for fiscal years. This involves reserving funds for the Act and adjusting subsections for better implementation. Amendments to Section 611 of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act include changes to fund allocation for fiscal years, such as adjusting subsections to ensure effective implementation. This involves inserting a clause to maintain the previous subsection's effect and modifying the appropriation language for clarity and availability of funds. Amendments to Section 611 of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act involve adjusting fund allocation for fiscal years by modifying appropriation language to ensure funds are available for effective implementation. Amendments to Section 611 of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act involve modifying appropriation language to ensure funds are available for effective implementation. This includes changes such as replacing "appropriated" with "available" in various clauses and subsections. SEC. 5. USE OF FUNDS UNDER THE INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES EDUCATION ACT. Section 613(a)(2)(C) of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is amended to allow local educational agencies to use up to 20 percent of funds received to provide additional funding for programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act allows local educational agencies to use up to 20 percent of funds for various education programs authorized under Federal or State law, such as school safety, teacher quality, after school learning, school reform, literacy, class size reduction, and school construction. The Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 2001.
